Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal #: CNS 11-26739
PI(s): Ullmer, Brygg
Batzer, Mark A.; Brenner, Sussanne C.; Butler, Leslie G.; Parker, Rod
Institution: Louisiana State University
Title: MRI/Dev.: Melete: An Interaction-oriented, Software-rich Compute Cluster with
Tangible Interface Support for Collaborative Research and the Classroom
Project Proposed:
This project, developing Melete, a new genre of interaction-oriented compute cluster instrument integrated with advanced interaction technologies, servicing research collaboration and training in computational science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics (STEAM), aims to advance the capabilities of batch processing systems. In decades past, batch processing meant turning over computation to a remote dispatcher, retrieving only the results of the isolated and distant computational process. As users have evolved to expect greater interactivity with their copious mobile devices and other forms of mobile computation, the evolution of the ?cloud? as a computational paradigm ha become much more interactive. Melete promises to extend this interactive paradigm to cluster computing in new and innovative ways.
The developed instrument will enable research in biology, visualization of computational materials, displaying configuration space for computational mathematics, mapping and displaying data from robot mapped locations (e.g. archeology sites, urban environments, etc), and architecture visualization.
Broader Impacts:
This proposal promises benefits to society by balancing activities between research and research training contexts. This approach is aligned with NSF priorities in cyberlearning, cyberinfrastructure, and beyond. The proposal's partnership with Southern University (an HBCU) in
both research and classroom impacts, building upon five years of successful collaboration in "Cybertools," provides further potential and promise for broader impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Melete MRI worked toward a new genre of interaction-oriented compute cluster integrated with advanced interaction technologies, servicing research collaboration and training in computational science, technology, engineering, arts, and mathematics (STEAM). It centered upon a software-rich compute cluster; and has emphasized connection of these to advanced interaction technologies.

Intellectual merit: In the early years of digital computing, virtually all computing was performed in batch. Today, most computing is highly interactive, with the notable exception of supercomputing. Moore’s Law suggests multi-hundred core machines may soon become the norm for personal com­­pu­ting devices. These prospects demand progress in interactive engagement with large parallel systems – both for research use, and perhaps especially in research training (including the classroom and class labs).

The Melete grant has allowed us to bring such capabilities into production both for research and research training impact. This work has ranged in emphasis from chemistry and tomography to computer graphics, software engineering to genomics, and beyond. Much of this work has included explicit engagement with human-computer interaction impacts.

Broader impacts: The Melete project has included major emphasis on broader impacts, as reported in several publications and art exhibitions. Some of this work has been in partnership with Southern University, a subcontract-supported HBCU partner. One system was co-created by an African-American high school student transitioning from a local high school. Ullmer has taught seven undergraduate-dominated classes that have conducted team projects on and engaging the Melete cluster. While our Melete efforts have taken many forms, the single largest broader impact effort has engaged interactive poster pilot projects. The development of physical face nodes, deployed primarily in hallway contexts, was another major broader impacts accomplishment.

Melete resulted in 17 publications.  19 students assisted in the instrument's development, and more than 100 students used the instrument in classes and their graduate + undergraduate research. Forty faculty participated either in development and/or use of the melete instrument.
